user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_init:
```c
void
MHD_init (void)
{
#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  WSADATA wsd;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */

  MHD_set_panic_func (NULL, NULL);

#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  if (0 != WSAStartup (MAKEWORD (2, 2), &wsd))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialize winsock.\n"));
  if ((2 != LOBYTE (wsd.wVersion)) && (2 != HIBYTE (wsd.wVersion)))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Winsock version 2.2 is not available.\n"));
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
#ifdef MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT
#if GCRYPT_VERSION_NUMBER < 0x010600
#if GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_pthread))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#elif defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_w32))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#endif /* defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_) */
#endif /* GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00 */
  gcry_check_version (NULL);
#else
  if (NULL == gcry_check_version ("1.6.0"))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("libgcrypt is too old. MHD was compiled for " \
                  "libgcrypt 1.6.0 or newer.\n"));
#endif
#endif /* MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT */
  gnutls_global_init ();
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  MHD_monotonic_sec_counter_init ();
  MHD_send_init_static_vars_ ();
  MHD_init_mem_pools_ ();
  /* Check whether sizes were correctly detected by configure */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  if (1)
  {
    struct timeval tv;
    mhd_assert (sizeof(tv.tv_sec) == SIZEOF_STRUCT_TIMEVAL_TV_SEC);
  }
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  mhd_assert (sizeof(uint64_t) == SIZEOF_UINT64_T);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_init:
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_set_panic_func (MHD_PanicCallback cb,
                    void *cls)
{
  if ((MHD_PanicCallback) NULL != cb)
    mhd_panic = cb;
  else
    mhd_panic = &mhd_panic_std;

  mhd_panic_cls = cls;
}
...
#define MHD_PANIC(msg) do{mhd_panic(mhd_panic_cls,__FILE__,__LINE__,msg);BUILTIN_NOT_REACHED;}while(0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if ((2 != LOBYTE (wsd.wVersion)) && (2 != HIBYTE (wsd.wVersion)))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Winsock version 2.2 is not available.\n"));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this fragment: the expression uses integer macros (LOBYTE/HIBYTE) on wsd.wVersion and then calls MHD_PANIC with a string literal. There is no pointer variable here that could be const-qualified. (Note: if the panic callback mhd_panic were declared to take a non-const char * for the message, that declaration — not this call site — would be the place to fix to satisfy Rule 8.13.)
